dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, [clears throat] today we're diving into, like, the big tech companies and, uh, their taxes. Or lack thereof, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, today we're diving into, like, the big tech companies and, uh, their taxes. Or lack thereof, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. I mean, Apple is, like, the poster child for this. Remember that Irish deal?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. I mean, Apple is, like, the poster child for this. Remember that Irish deal?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple has become the poster child for corporate tax avoidance, with its legal claim that a few hundred people working in Ireland were the real source of its profits, and then striking a deal with that countrys government that resulted in its paying a tax amounting to .005% of its profit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The 0.005% tax? [chuckles] I mean, come on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The zero point zero zero five percent tax? I mean, come on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple has become the poster child for corporate tax avoidance...striking a deal with that countrys government that resulted in its paying a tax amounting to .005% of its profit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild. And they all claim to be so socially responsible, but, you know, paying your fair share? That's kinda step one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild. And they all claim to be so socially responsible, but, you know, paying your fair share? That's kinda step one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple, Google, Starbucks, and companies like them all claim to be socially responsible, but the first element of social responsibility should be paying your fair share of tax.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously. If everyone just, like, avoided taxes like that, society would just crumble. No roads, no internet...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously. If everyone just, like, avoided taxes like that, society would just crumble. No roads, no internet...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If everyone avoided and evaded taxes like these companies, society could not function, much less make the public investments that led to the Internet, on which Apple and Google depend.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And that internet they depend on? Public investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And that internet they depend on? Public investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If everyone avoided and evaded taxes like these companies, society could not function, much less make the public investments that led to the Internet, on which Apple and Google depend.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's this whole "race to the bottom" thing, too. Countries competing to lower their corporate taxes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's this whole race to the bottom thing, too. Countries competing to lower their corporate taxes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For years, multinational corporations have encouraged a race to the bottom, telling each country that it must lower its taxes below that of its competitors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and, um, Trump's 2017 tax cut really culminated that. Now the "sugar high" is fading, leaving tons of debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and, um, Trump's twenty seventeen tax cut really culminated that. Now the sugar high is fading, leaving tons of debt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US President Donald Trumps 2017 tax cut culminated that race. A year later, we can see the results: the sugar high it brought to the US economy is quickly fading, leaving behind a mountain of debt (which increased by more than $1 trillion dollars last year).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the core issue with the current system, like, this "transfer pricing"?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's the core issue with the current system, like, this transfer pricing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's supposed to tax where economic activity happens. But how do you even determine that when a product, like, a wafer, crosses borders multiple times unfinished?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's supposed to tax where economic activity happens. But how do you even determine that when a product, like, a wafer, crosses borders multiple times unfinished?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Transfer pricing relies on the well-accepted principle that taxes should reflect where an economic activity occurs. But how is that determined? In a globalized economy, products move repeatedly across borders, typically in an unfinished state: a shirt without buttons, a car without a transmission, a wafer without a chip.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's really tough. Especially with intellectual property, right? You can just move ownership around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's really tough. Especially with intellectual property, right? You can just move ownership around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The growing role of intellectual property and intangibles makes matters even worse, because ownership claims can easily be moved around the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. The US actually stopped using transfer pricing internally years ago, for states. They use a formula.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. The U S actually stopped using transfer pricing internally years ago, for states. They use a formula.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats why the United States long ago abandoned using the transfer price system within the US, in favor of a formula that attributes companies total profits to each state in proportion to the share of sales, employment, and capital there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we need that globally? [interrupts] But wouldn't a formula based mostly on sales hurt developing countries?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we need that globally? But wouldn't a formula based mostly on sales hurt developing countries?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the formula is based largely on final sales, which occur disproportionately in developed countries, developing countries will be deprived of needed revenues, which will be increasingly missed as fiscal constraints diminish aid flows.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, absolutely. That's why you gotta include employment, too. And, um, a global minimum corporate tax.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, absolutely. That's why you gotta include employment, too. And, um, a global minimum corporate tax.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Final sales may be appropriate for taxation of digital transactions, but not for manufacturing or other sectors, where it is vital to include employment as well. ... The appropriate response to this concern is to impose a global minimum corporate-income tax.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That makes a lot of sense. So, like, the EU and the US could, you know, just start that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That makes a lot of sense. So, like, the E U and the U S could, you know, just start that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US and the European Union could and should do this on their own.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they could, and others would follow. Stop this race where only the multinationals win.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they could, and others would follow. Stop this race where only the multinationals win.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If they did, others would follow, preventing a race in which only the multinationals win.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But, uh, politics always gets in the way, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, uh, politics always gets in the way, doesn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Always. Multinationals push for reforms that keep the tax avoidance going, and some governments, well, they listen.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Always. Multinationals push for reforms that keep the tax avoidance going, and some governments, well, they listen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Politics matters: the multinationals objective is to gain support for reforms that continue the race to the bottom and maintain opportunities for tax avoidance. Governments in some advanced countries where these companies have significant political influence will support these efforts even if doing so disadvantages the rest of the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it needs to be about actual principles, then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it needs to be about actual principles, then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. About the well-being of the billions in developing countries, not just, you know, corporate profits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. About the well-being of the billions in developing countries, not just, you know, corporate profits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the goal is genuine inclusiveness, the top priority must be the wellbeing of the more than six billion people living in developing countries and emerging markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a truly inclusive framework.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a truly inclusive framework.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely.
